text: Same as <@U016VHYUM7Z> I block out time in my calendar e. g. for online courses, personal development stuff, research and sometimes even reflection on a particular topic or issue. If it's a paid-for course, yes, I'd use the up-front-payment as a motivator to actually go and do it.

text:
Hi all! I'm working to improve the headlines we use across our content (blog posts, podcast episode titles, etc). Our go-to tactic is to write out at least 15 headlines for everything we publish based on various formulas and what we've seen working the past. (The first 5 headlines are easy-ish, 6-10 quite hard, 11-15 you're really scrambling for ideas... and this is where the good stuff usually appears.)

But I'm wondering... does anyone else have any go-to tactics for writing great headlines?

elements.text:

text:
Here's a thing I'm terrible at: estimating how long a content project will take. I need to bid a website project -- not the articles, but the UX copy/branding stuff that wraps around the articles. Any advice and/or metrics tools for scoping that stuff?

Things I understand: bake in revision time, client time, research and ramp up on subject matter. Things I don't understand: I gotta write a page of CTAs, how long does that take? I gotta write hero copy, how long does that take? I have a good site map to work from, FYI.

I should be able to do this by now, but I swear, my projects are all so different, the clients all so different... Help? Thank you.

elements.text:
Here's a thing I'm terrible at: estimating how long a content project will take. I need to bid a website project -- not the articles, but the UX copy/branding stuff that wraps around the articles. Any advice and/or metrics tools for scoping that stuff?

Things I understand: bake in revision time, client time, research and ramp up on subject matter. Things I don't understand: I gotta write a page of CTAs, how long does that take? I gotta write hero copy, how long does that take? I have a good site map to work from, FYI.

I should be able to do this by now, but I swear, my projects are all so different, the clients all so different... Help? Thank you.

text:
Hey Ash! I recently <https://www.activecampaign.com/blog/attention-grabbing-headlines|wrote about this for ActiveCampaign>.

I think there's no substitute for writing a lot of headlines, but also that you won't get the benefits of volume by approaching each new headline from the same frame.

When I write a lot of headlines, I'll do it in batches targeting a particular style. For example:
• Target the pain point the article solves
• Targets the value proposition of the article (slightly different from above)
• Listicle style
• Question style
• Pull a single compelling detail from the article
• Make an unexpected comparison that the article supports
• Describe the article itself (e.g. "In 1013 words you'll learn...")
• And many more
One thing I do with every headline is put it through the "5 curiosity methods" – I pulled them from a behavioral economics paper, and describe them in <https://www.activecampaign.com/blog/attention-grabbing-headlines|the headline article>.

Of course all of this gets messier and more annoying when SEO is the priority :shrug:

attachments.title: How to Write Attention-Grabbing Headlines (Better than This One)
attachments.text: Learn how to write attention-grabbing headlines — without banging your head against a wall. Headline examples, fundamentals, and insights from copy experts.
attachments.fallback: How to Write Attention-Grabbing Headlines (Better than This One)

text:
I’m also a practitioner of the write-a-lot-of-headlines method. I like to plug mine into CoSchedule’s Headline Analyzer tool. It helps me to think critically about my word choices and structure. I also like to see the headline as it would appear in SERPs.

<https://coschedule.com/headline-analyzer>

attachments.title: Write Better Headlines: Headline Analyzer From CoSchedule - @CoSchedule
attachments.text: The Headline Analyzer that will score your overall headline quality and rate its ability to result in social shares, increased traffic, and SEO value.
attachments.fallback: Write Better Headlines: Headline Analyzer From CoSchedule - @CoSchedule

elements.text: I’m also a practitioner of the write-a-lot-of-headlines method. I like to plug mine into CoSchedule’s Headline Analyzer tool. It helps me to think critically about my word choices and structure. I also like to see the headline as it would appear in SERPs.

text: Digital Marketer has a practice called The Michigan Method. It’s a grid. Top row is different target market niches. Column is stuff like: have before/have now, status, feel before/feel after, good vs evil, and some other ones (I forget at the moment). I find you can skip around and fill them out. You get between 12-16 depending. I really like it.

elements.text: Digital Marketer has a practice called The Michigan Method. It’s a grid. Top row is different target market niches. Column is stuff like: have before/have now, status, feel before/feel after, good vs evil, and some other ones (I forget at the moment). I find you can skip around and fill them out. You get between 12-16 depending. I really like it.

text: What’s your take on sharing the same social media caption/content across platforms? I heard recently that it’s bad for SEO, but obviously it saves a ton of time in creation and ideation. Thanks in advance for any insight!

elements.text: What’s your take on sharing the same social media caption/content across platforms? I heard recently that it’s bad for SEO, but obviously it saves a ton of time in creation and ideation. Thanks in advance for any insight!

text: In personal experience, I've never seen it negatively impact SEO. We have articles pulling in 1000s of views per week and #1 on google. We share them with the same caption for the most-part as social is secondary for us.

elements.text: In personal experience, I've never seen it negatively impact SEO. We have articles pulling in 1000s of views per week and #1 on google. We share them with the same caption for the most-part as social is secondary for us.

text: I have a very similar experience to Dom's. No negative impact for us. We consistently rank in position 0 or 1, and we share the same captions across platforms for all our content.

elements.text: I have a very similar experience to Dom's. No negative impact for us. We consistently rank in position 0 or 1, and we share the same captions across platforms for all our content.

text: Social media shares have zero impact on ranking.

elements.text: Social media shares have zero impact on ranking.

text: Don't stress it :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Don't stress it

text: Also haven’t seen any impact on SEO, but I still tweak the caption depending on the audience of the platform.

elements.text: Also haven’t seen any impact on SEO, but I still tweak the caption depending on the audience of the platform.

text: I'm not sure if it has impact on your site's SEO but it's definitely wise to change the captions for different social channels. For example, you shouldn't use the same tone on Facebook and LinkedIn since folks perceive the platforms differently.

elements.text: I'm not sure if it has impact on your site's SEO but it's definitely wise to change the captions for different social channels. For example, you shouldn't use the same tone on Facebook and LinkedIn since folks perceive the platforms differently.

text: Thanks all! That was my inclination, but I’d heard the opposite recently, so I wanted so more opinions.

elements.text: Thanks all! That was my inclination, but I’d heard the opposite recently, so I wanted so more opinions.

text:
I feel like all of this varies project by project. I got advice when I was starting my biz to take the last 3 semi-similar projects I've done in this area and average them out so you'll know timing for next time.

Also - track your time on your projects! (At least in the beginning.) You won't know how long coming up with a page of CTAs takes you unless you measure your own process. :slightly_smiling_face:

Also, I'd bid higher for anything closer to the "sale"... so any copy around checkout pages, sales pages etc. VS landing pages, which were further from the same.

May not help a whole bunch, but maybe a little?

elements.text:

Also, I'd bid higher for anything closer to the "sale"... so any copy around checkout pages, sales pages etc. VS landing pages, which were further from the same.

May not help a whole bunch, but maybe a little?

text: Hi all. I'm a one-woman content marketing show and feel at the tipping point of growing the team, but unsure how to approach pitching another FT hire or more freelance resources. Anyone with experience in scaling from one to a team or one to an army of freelancers -- and how to make the decision between those two paths? Thanks!

elements.text: Hi all. I'm a one-woman content marketing show and feel at the tipping point of growing the team, but unsure how to approach pitching another FT hire or more freelance resources. Anyone with experience in scaling from one to a team or one to an army of freelancers -- and how to make the decision between those two paths? Thanks!

text: I work for the online learning platform edX, and currently manage content efforts across B2C, B2B, and B2E (higher ed), including two blog properties, gated longer form resources and case studies (have a freelancer helping out with some of that now), and starting on some short video content. A lot on my plate, could use freelancers for various pieces of that (like how I use for longer form resources now) or was thinking it could be valuable to tack on another FT, more junior-level generalist that can help crank out written pieces and/or focus on supporting one biz line

text: I think an army of freelancers works well when you just need to scale production of written content and that’s it. The limitation there will still be you, but you can invest your time in properly briefing, managing and editing their work instead of just your own. However, if you need support on internal collaboration, editing, working with partners, etc. — or when managing freelancers alone becomes a full-time job in and of itself — that’s when it’s often time to hire someone internally.

elements.text: I think an army of freelancers works well when you just need to scale production of written content and that’s it. The limitation there will still be you, but you can invest your time in properly briefing, managing and editing their work instead of just your own. However, if you need support on internal collaboration, editing, working with partners, etc. — or when managing freelancers alone becomes a full-time job in and of itself — that’s when it’s often time to hire someone internally.

text:
In terms of pitching and getting approval, you have 2 levers:
1. What is the company’s strategy and is our team properly resourced to support that?
2. What are my career goals and, assuming the company is interested in supporting those, does your current role help you achieve those?

elements.text: In terms of pitching and getting approval, you have 2 levers:
What is the company’s strategy and is our team properly resourced to support that?
What are my career goals and, assuming the company is interested in supporting those, does your current role help you achieve those?

text: Another great formula is ETC(End Result, Time to get it, Conquor Objections). Very similar approach to previous comments. <https://www.marketingprofs.com/articles/2020/43158/an-easy-three-step-headline-formula-that-grabs-customer-attention-in-just-five-minutes-with-examples?adref=nlt070920&spMailingID=42912355&spUserID=MTA0ODUyODU0NDQzOQS2&spJobID=1800684781&spReportId=MTgwMDY4NDc4MQS2>
